section.title: Third Conditional
section.sectiontitle:
Use the Third Conditional form to talk hypothetically about past situations, and
imagine different consequences if + Past Perfect + would have + past participle
section.text2: There was a lot of traffic. I was late for the meeting.
section.text2a: If there hadn't been so much traffic on the motorway, I would have got to the meeting on time.
section.text1: She didn't study art. She was unhappy.
section.text1a: If she had studied art, she would have been happier.
section.sectiontitle2: To indicate possibility, rather than certainty, we can also use might have/could have instead of would have.
section.text3: She didn't study hard. She failed her exams.
section.text3a: If she had studied harder, she might have passed her exams.
section.text4: I left work early. I didn't finish the report.
section.text4a: If I hadn't left work early, I could have finished the report.

section.title: Third Conditional
section.sectiontitle: These unreal past situations have unreal past results.
section.text2a: If I had finished my university degree, I would have found a job immediately.
section.text1a: If you hadn't forgotten her address I would have written to her.
section.sectiontitle2:
Sometimes the hypothetical past situation has a present result;
if + Past Perfect + would + verb
section.text3a: If I had finished my university degree, I would be an architect now.
section.text4a: If I hadn't forgotten her address I would write to her now.
